originalTitle: Suspected carbon-monoxide leak kills at least 30 miners in Nigeria, witnesses say
title: Suspected carbon-monoxide leak kills at least 30 miners in Nigeria, witnesses say
content: The workers are believed to have collapsed after the gas built up in poorly ventilated tunnels.

originalTitle: Social media suspended in Gabon for 'spreading of false information'
title: News from Gabon: Social Media Takes a Little Break!
content:
Hello from Africa!

Hello, my wonderful friends! I'm your super happy news reporter, bringing you stories from our amazing continent, Africa. Today, we have an important message from a country called Gabon. Gabon is a beautiful country in Central Africa, with lots of green forests and cool animals. Did you know? Africa is a huge continent with 54 different countries! Each one is special and full of unique people and places.

What Happened in Gabon?

Something important happened in Gabon recently. The grown-ups who help keep things safe and orderly made a big decision. They decided to turn off some popular apps that many people use every day. These apps are called social media. Imagine if your favourite game on a tablet or phone suddenly stopped working. That's a little bit like what happened for people using social media in Gabon. It’s like these apps have gone on a little holiday or a quiet nap. This means that for a while, people in Gabon cannot use apps like Facebook, WhatsApp, or Twitter. These are some of the places where people share pictures, send messages, and talk to their friends and family.

What is Social Media?

Let's talk a little bit about social media. It's like a big online playground where grown-ups and some older kids can chat and share things. Think of it like a giant letter-writing club, but super fast! People use social media to say hello to their friends, even if they live very far away. They can share photos of their pets, tell everyone about their day, or even wish someone a happy birthday. It helps people feel connected. Did you know? Many people in Africa use WhatsApp to talk to their family members who might be in another city or even another country! It helps them stay close. But just like any playground, sometimes things can go wrong. Sometimes, not everyone plays fair, and that's where our story from Gabon comes in.

Why Did They Turn it Off?

Now, the big question: why did the grown-ups in Gabon decide to pause social media? They said it was because of 'false information'. That's a grown-up way of saying 'stories that are not true'. Imagine someone telling a story that isn't real. Maybe they say that the sky is green, or that elephants can fly! That's a made-up story, or false information. It's not true. When people share stories that are not true online, it can make others confused. It can even make people worried or scared for no reason. It's like shouting 'fire!' when there is no fire. It causes problems. So, the people in charge in Gabon felt that too many untrue stories were being shared. They thought these false stories could cause trouble and make people unhappy or confused. That's why they decided to give social media a little break. Did you know? It's always important to think before you share a story. Ask yourself: 'Is this really true?' If you are not sure, it's best not to share it.

Who Decided This?

Who are these grown-ups who made this decision? They are called the 'media regulator'. Think of them like the school principal for news and stories. Their job is to make sure that the news and information people see and hear are fair and true. They want to make sure everyone gets the right information, so they can make good choices. They are like the watchdogs for stories, making sure no one is telling tall tales that could cause harm. So, the media regulator in Gabon looked at all the untrue stories being shared on social media and decided it was time to step in and stop it for a while.

When Will it Come Back?

This is another important part of the story. The grown-ups in Gabon said the social media would be turned off 'until further notice'. What does that mean? It means they don't know exactly when it will come back on. It's like when you're waiting for a rainy day to clear up – you don't know the exact minute the sun will shine again. You just have to wait and see. So, people in Gabon are waiting for the media regulator to say it's safe and okay for social media to be turned back on. They are hoping that when it does come back, people will be more careful about sharing true stories. Did you know? Patience is very important! Sometimes we have to wait for good things to happen, just like people in Gabon are waiting for their social media apps to come back online.

How Does This Affect People?

Not being able to use social media can be hard for many people in Gabon. Imagine not being able to quickly send a message to your auntie or see what your cousin is doing. People might feel a bit lonely or out of touch with friends and family who live far away. It changes how they communicate every day. They might have to use other ways to talk, like regular phone calls or sending letters. It also means that news and other information might travel slower. People have to find other ways to know what's happening in their town or country.

Why Is It Important to Share True Stories?

This whole story reminds us how important it is to share true stories. When we share things that are real and correct, it helps everyone stay safe and smart. Untrue stories can cause confusion, anger, or even make people think wrong things. Being honest and truthful helps us all get along better and understand the world in the right way. Did you know? Being truthful is one of the best ways to be a good friend and a good citizen! It helps build trust between people.

What Can We Learn?

So, what can we learn from this news from Gabon? We learn that even though social media can be a lot of fun and very helpful, we must use it carefully. We should always try to make sure the stories we see and share are true. If you ever see something online and you're not sure if it's real, it's always best to ask a grown-up, like your parent or teacher. It's like crossing the road – always stop, look, and listen before you go! With stories online, always stop, think, and ask before you share. This helps keep our online world safe and happy for everyone, just like we want our beautiful Africa to be!
summary: In Gabon, a country in Africa, grown-ups decided to temporarily turn off social media apps like Facebook and WhatsApp because too many untrue stories were being shared, which could confuse or worry people.
whyMatters: This matters because sharing stories that are not true can cause problems and make people feel scared or confused, so it's important for everyone to learn how to tell the difference between real stories and made-up ones to keep our communities safe and happy.

title: Eight skiers found dead after California avalanche
content: Fifteen skiers went missing on Tuesday following a massive avalanche in California's Lake Tahoe region. One person remains missing but is presumed dead.

title: Do not give away Diego Garcia, Trump tells UK in fresh attack on Chagos deal
content: The president's comments come just a day after the US gave its official backing to the UK's Chagos deal.

content: Benfica claim there is a "defamation campaign" against Gianluca Prestianni as Uefa launch an investigation into claims he racially abused Real Madrid's Vinicius Jr.
